subQuestions.title: How does life change for graduates after university?

options.f2c4c259-f18a-404e-a96f-18a0ba4ed8ee: They feel more stressed about job seeking
options.af59103c-6134-487a-8e9b-04d9b0cb6dfc: They are likely to stick to their academic routines

subQuestions.title: What is a common characteristic of the job market after university?

content.questionName: Lis Part 4 - Topic : life after university
content.listeningScript:
Life after university is quite an adventure, and I’ve learned a lot since graduating last year. The biggest change I’ve noticed is how different my daily routine is now. Unlike during my university days, I don’t have a fixed schedule of classes and study sessions anymore. This has actually made me more adaptable and willing to try new things. I’ve found myself saying ‘yes’ to opportunities I might have passed up before, whether it’s joining a new club or learning a new skill for work.

Speaking of work, one big thing I’ve always heard that finding a job would be tough, but I didn’t realize just how fierce the competition would be. It seems like every position has dozens, if not hundreds, of applicants, meaning you really have to stand out to get noticed. On the bright side, this competitive environment has pushed me to improve my skills and broaden my network. I’ve attended more networking events in the past year than I ever did at university.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing information and technology . Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: The future generation will fail to cope with new information     tentisspace
The information revolution will be good for the economy     tentisspace
No computer is superior to the human brain     tentisspace
More should be done to protect individual privacy     tentisspace

content.questionName: Lis - Part 3 - Topic : information and technology - Nữ nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Woman: What are you doing? You seem up to your neck in work.

Man: Yeah, I’m working on an assignment about the Information Revolution.

Woman: The Information Revolution? What’s that about?

Man: It’s basically a concept describing how information technology has transformed the way people live and work.

Woman: Really? That sounds complicated. I can never imagine what the future of humans and technology will look like. It feels like we’re just collecting more and more data without really using it to its full potential.

Man: Well, the current information systems are already incredibly advanced. They can complete tasks and solve problems for humans — and I’m sure they’ll only keep improving from here.

Woman: I can’t picture that kind of future, especially when everything seems so overwhelming and fast-paced.

Man: Think of it this way: information itself has become a commodity. It’s being bought and sold, forming an entire industry that contributes to economic growth.

Woman: Yes, but as long as it doesn’t replace real people in their jobs. That could have a really detrimental impact on society.

Man: True, but I think that’s an unavoidable consequence. Throughout history, humans have always had to adapt and change in order to evolve.

Woman: You seem to be on the optimistic side. I honestly believe manual labor is — and will continue to be — completely replaced by machines.

Man: That’s possible, but like any revolution in the past, while some jobs disappear, new ones will be created. In the end, humans will still remain in control — especially of the things they’ve invented themselves.

Woman: Is there anything that concerns you about this whole Information Revolution?

Man: I think people should be more aware of what they do online. The internet is a global space where everything can be tracked, even after you think you’ve erased it.

Woman: Absolutely. I’m often shocked by how careless many young people are when it comes to sharing personal information. You’re literally one click away from exposing yourself to serious risks without even realizing it.

content.questionName: Lis - Part 3 - Topic : internet - Nữ nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Woman: Hi, Emma. You know, I’ve been thinking a lot about how much the internet has improved lately. It’s really starting to shape the way our lives develop.

Man: Really? In what way?

Woman: Well, take a look at this article I found. It talks about how the internet influences everything—from how we learn to how we make decisions.

Man: Ah, so you’re saying the internet gives us access to a lot of information? That's true in my opinion.

Woman: Hmm… not exactly. Not exactly. I think the information is helpful, but you actually need strong searching skills to find what’s useful. And the problem is, too many people fall for fake news.

Man: That’s a fair point. Just last week, I saw this post about a new product that promises fast weight loss. It had thousands of likes and comments, but when I looked into it, it turned out to be a complete scam.

Woman: That’s a perfect example. I really believe there should be stricter control. Authorities need to take legal action and provide clearer guidelines. The internet has a huge impact on the way people think and behave.

Man: I’m not sure I agree with that part. I think we just need to be more careful when using the internet. People should take responsibility to double-check things before buying or sharing. If we bring in too many laws, we might limit people’s freedom to express their opinions.

Woman: I get your point, but still, we can’t ignore the damage some of this content causes. There’s so much being created every second—especially short-form content. It’s fast and addictive. And honestly, I think it’s making young people more impatient.

Man: I completely agree. My younger cousin can’t even sit through a one-minute video without skipping ahead. It’s like no one wants to wait anymore.

Woman: Exactly. That’s why I think some sort of regulation is necessary—not to control people’s voices, but to help improve the quality of what we see online.

Man: That might help, as long as we don’t go too far with restrictions.

content.questionName: Lis - Part 3 - Topic : University and technology - Nữ nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Woman: That looks interesting. What are you up to?

Man: Oh, I just came across this interesting report about universities and how they’re evolving in the digital age. It talked about the impact of the internet, student experiences, and even competition between institutions. It got me thinking, there’s so much to unpack when it comes to how education is changing, don’t you think?

Woman: Yeah, I’ve been reading about similar things lately. It’s amazing how different opinions can be on what makes a good university experience. I think we can both agree that the internet has made education more accessible. It’s great how people from different backgrounds can now access high-quality education without being physically present.

Man: Absolutely, I agree with that. It’s a game-changer for those who can’t afford to relocate or attend in person. But I still believe that social interactions are a crucial part of university life. Online education can never truly replace the friendships, group work, and networking that happen in a physical setting.

Woman: Hmm, I’m not so sure. While social interactions can be important, I think online learning allows students to focus more on their studies without all the distractions of campus life. Not everyone benefits from that kind of environment.

Man: I see your point, but I think universities provide a unique space for students to develop their social skills alongside their academic ones. That’s why I believe competition between universities can benefit students. When universities compete, it drives innovation and pushes them to offer better resources.

Woman: I disagree there. Competition can sometimes lead to universities focusing too much on rankings and flashy features instead of the quality of education. It can become more about marketing than genuine improvement.

Man: That’s a fair concern. But competition also forces universities to constantly improve, which can benefit students in the long run. What about the diversity in curricula? I’m curious where you stand on that.

Woman: To be honest, I’m not a fan of having too much variety in the curriculum. A diverse curriculum sounds exciting in theory, but it can overwhelm students and take away from the depth of learning in core subjects.

Man: I can see that perspective, but I think having variety gives students the flexibility to explore new areas of interest, which can lead to better preparation for the world after graduation.

content.questionName: Lis Thursday - Part 4 - Topic : two famous writers
content.listeningScript:
Today, I’d like to talk about two of the most influential writers in history: William Shakespeare and Louis Michael. Both of these figures have left a lasting mark on literature, yet, interestingly, their contributions have often been overlooked by academics throughout various periods in history. Shakespeare, of course, is a household name, known for his plays and sonnets that explore the depths of human emotion and experience. However, there was a time when scholars dismissed his works as "too common," underestimating their complexity. On the other hand, Louis Michael, whose works have reshaped modern storytelling, has yet to receive the recognition he truly deserves. His focus on social issues, mixed with poetic symbolism, is often underappreciated in academic circles.

What these two writers have in common is that they both challenge readers to look beyond the surface. It is not always easy for the meanings in their works to be identified. With Shakespeare, the language can be dense, making it difficult to grasp the deeper themes. Louis Michael, in contrast, weaves intricate layers of metaphor and allegory into his writing, requiring careful thought and analysis. Yet, once these hidden meanings are uncovered, the richness of their works becomes undeniable.

subQuestions.title: According to the expert, what is the public attitude towards sleeping?

options.547bfdfb-0897-4355-bab7-2095558c609c: The younger generation tends to have unhealthy sleeping habits.
options.e8ffeebd-360e-41db-a08b-413aa5b18870: Sleep quality has deteriorated over time.

content.questionName: Lis Thursday - Part 4 - Topic : the importance of sleep
content.listeningScript:
Sleep is very important for our health, but there are many ideas about it that are not entirely true. Many people think they can adjust to fewer hours of sleep, but not getting enough is very damaging, especially for students or workers. There’s also the argument that sleep is not as critical as diet and exercise, but this is questionable. What everyone agrees on is that blocking noise and light at night helps one to sleep better. It is important to sleep regularly. Darkness helps signal the body to rest, which is one reason that noise makes us feel less sleepy while silence allows us to rest better.

Some say that sleep is getting worse for people today, but there is no solid proof to support this claim. Critics often point fingers at the younger generation for their unhealthy sleep patterns, but this is sometimes unfair. What we can agree on is that the medical trend to overemphasize the subject makes it more serious than it really needs to be.

content.questionName: Lis Thursday - Part 2 - Topic : Listening to music
content.listeningScript:
Speaker A:

What I love to do after every busy day, after studying, is listen to music to relax. When I get home, I usually put on some slow songs, lie down for a while, and let my mind rest. Music helps me forget stress and feel calm again. It’s my favourite way to end the day.

Speaker B:

I love listening to pop music, especially while singing. Sometimes I turn on my favourite playlist and sing along loudly in my room. It makes me feel happy and more confident. Even when I’m tired, singing with music gives me a lot of energy.

Speaker C:

Most of my friends play music to relax or have some fun, but I usually listen to music while studying. I choose soft background music because it helps me focus better. If it’s too loud, I can’t concentrate, so I keep the volume low and study more effectively.

Speaker D:

My brother listens to music to relax, and he does it right after waking up. Every morning, he turns on music while getting ready for the day. He says it helps him feel awake and start the morning in a good mood.

Announcer: Good evening, everyone! Today, we’re excited to talk about the latest novel by popular author James Parker. He is known for his softer, romantic stories like Whispers of the Heart, which have touched the hearts of many readers. However, his new novel, Shadow in the Night, is quite different.

In Shadow in the Night, Parker explores a thrilling world of suspense and mystery. He moves away from his gentle love stories to deliver an exciting plot filled with unexpected twists. The tension in this book is much higher, showing that he can write in different styles.

While many readers are excited about this new direction, I believe it’s important for Parker to pay attention to the critics’ advice as he works on his next book. Their feedback can help him improve his writing and find the right balance between romance and thrill that fans appreciate. Stay tuned for more updates on this talented author!

content.questionName: Lis Tea - Part 4 - Topic : manage personal finances
content.listeningScript:
Good afternoon, everyone! Today, I want to share a few simple tips on how you can manage your personal finances better. Now, I know that saving money can sometimes feel challenging, but there are a few habits that can make it easier. One of the best ways to save effectively is to set aside a fixed amount every month. I recommend you make this a habit. You can even automate it by setting up a transfer from your checking account to your savings account. This way, the money is put aside before you even get a chance to spend it. If you just wait until the end of the month to save whatever is left over, there’s a good chance there won’t be much left—especially with all the small, unexpected expenses that pop up. So, it’s all about making saving a priority and keeping it consistent.

Now, when it comes to managing your finances overall, one key piece of advice is to get help from people who know more than you. That could mean speaking with a financial advisor if you’re able, but it could also mean getting advice from someone in your life who’s really good with money—whether that’s a friend, a family member, or even an online resource. You don’t have to figure everything out on your own. Learning from others can save you time and help you avoid costly mistakes, especially if you’re new to budgeting or long-term planning.

Remember, managing money doesn’t have to be complicated. By saving regularly and learning from others, you can start to feel more confident about your finances.

content.questionName: Lis 7h45 - Part 4 - Topic : experience in writing
content.listeningScript:
Hi everyone! I’d like to share my experience with writer’s block during the process of writing my new bestseller. Many people think that to write well, you need to sit down every day for 15 to 20 minutes or find a quiet space. While those strategies work for some, I’ve found that establishing specific time slots for writing that truly fit my style is what helps me the most.

However, I did face significant writer’s block at one point, and looking back, I regret not reaching out for guidance from others. I thought I could handle everything on my own, but sometimes it’s vital to get an outside perspective. Talking to fellow writers and mentors could have helped me overcome that block much faster. Now I understand that collaboration and sharing ideas can inspire creativity. So, if you ever find yourself stuck, don’t hesitate to reach out to others!

options.8b4fb2d9-b981-441e-b098-5f7897997ea2: Many believe they are only useful after incidents have occurred.
options.18a3c665-2337-4426-b647-0a06ea7e28c1: People should feel reassured about their presence.

content.questionName: Lis 7h45 - Part 4 - Topic : Security cameras
content.listeningScript:
People should feel reassured about their presence.

Transcript:

I’ve noticed that some of my coworkers get a bit nervous about the security cameras in our office. They often say things like, ‘It feels like we’re being watched all the time,’ or ‘I don’t like feeling like I’m not trusted.’ But honestly, I think people worry too much about it. These cameras aren’t there to spy on us or catch us doing something wrong. They’re actually there to keep us safe. I mean, think about it – if something were to happen, like a theft or an accident, wouldn’t you want there to be a record of it?

Plus, knowing the cameras are there can actually prevent bad things from happening in the first place. I believe that once people understand the real purpose of these cameras, they’ll feel much better about them. Instead of feeling worried, we should feel glad that our company cares about our safety. It’s just one more way they’re looking out for us while we’re at work.

You know, I remember when we first got the cameras installed. Some people were really upset about it. But after a while, most of us hardly even notice them anymore. They’re just part of the background now. And there have been occasions where they’ve been really helpful. Like when someone’s bag went missing, the cameras helped us figure out what happened.

It’s important to remember that these cameras are in public areas, not in private spaces like bathrooms or changing rooms. They’re not meant to invade our privacy, just to make sure everyone follows the rules and stays safe. In the end, I think having them makes our workplace better for everyone. It’s a small thing that can make a big difference in keeping us all secure.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing music and singers. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Singer can be good models for the young
Taste in music is a highly personal thing
Music is a universal language
Music can be used to manipulate people’s feelings.

content.questionName: Lis - Part 3 - Topic : music and singer - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hi Michael, have you heard about the new awards for young artists?

Woman: Yeah, it’s a major event! It’s inspiring to see young artists motivating the next generation.

Man: What exactly do you mean by that?

Woman: Many singers participate in charity work and donate money, which encourages their fans to give back as well.

Man: True, but I feel they aren’t always doing it solely for the sake of helping others.

Woman: I don’t think that’s entirely fair. It seems like you might be overlooking their talent and contributions to society.

Man: Well, I just don’t like them. So what?

Woman: Don’t you think that’s a bit subjective? Different generations have different tastes. For instance, traditional music we enjoy isn’t appealing to everyone; some find it dull.

Man: Absolutely. Music preferences are definitely personal. But honestly, I feel many contemporary artists don’t measure up to those from the ’90s.

Woman: What do you mean by that?

Man: I think music, as a form of emotional expression, can connect people globally, regardless of their background.

Woman: Maybe, but I can’t fully agree. Perhaps it’s because I don’t have an artistic background like you. You went to art school, right?

Man: Yes, but formal training isn’t necessary to appreciate art. For example, films use music to influence the audience’s emotions.

Woman: True. Sometimes music can make us feel emotions we weren’t expecting. But in some movies, the music feels overdone, like the drums force the feeling too much.

Man: That usually comes down to poor execution. When done correctly, music should enhance the scene naturally without drawing attention to itself.

Woman: That’s a good point. Subtle music really can elevate the overall experience without overpowering the viewer.

content.questionName: Lis 7h45 - Part 2 - Topic : Protect the environment 1
content.listeningScript:
F: There are many small things we can do to reduce our impact on the planet. Many people may adopt hobbies such as recycling or using public transportation. For me, it's really simple. I just turn off the lights or any unnecessary household appliances when I'm not at home. These things seem small and rather insignificant, but you would be surprised by how much they can reduce your monthly electricity bill.


M: Everybody seems to be buying things online these days, but I live near a supermarket, so I often go there for my groceries. In fact, my apartment is situated in quite a convenient area. There are lanes for bicycles as well, so every day I either walk or cycle to work. These activities not only allow me to be healthier but are also simple ways for anyone to reduce their carbon footprint and contribute to a greener lifestyle.


F: I have my groceries delivered to my door, which is very convenient. I believe many people nowadays do this as a way to avoid the terrible traffic in cities and to look for better deals. However, I would say this is also an effective approach to live more sustainably, similar to not driving cars too much or using less electricity.


M: I would love to walk or cycle to work, but I live far from my workplace and the train system isn’t that great. Therefore, I have no choice but to drive my own car. However, I do find other ways to limit my impact on the environment. Small actions such as turning off the tap or taking a shower instead of a bath are great examples. I believe everyone should do their bit to preserve the natural world

content.questionName: Lis 6h30 - Part 2 - Topic : Work from home
content.listeningScript:
1. Working from home has its pros and cons, and I have mixed feelings about it. On one hand, I find that I work effectively without the distractions of my colleagues chatting. However, I get distracted by other things at home, like household chores and family, during the workday. I also miss being able to go out and complete things much faster. It's nice to set my own schedule and take breaks when I want. However, working from home is not as good as expected. I sometimes feel lonely without the social interaction that comes with the office. Video calls are helpful, but they can't replace face-to-face conversations.
  2. You don't need a big home office to be productive; a small corner of your room can work just fine. Still, it's important to stay self-motivated, which can be challenging at times. After all, how well you work from home really depends on your situation and personality. Some people thrive in this environment, while others struggle. Overall, I am learning to balance my work and personal life better as I adjust to this new way of working.

options.6378836d-886e-4dc0-b767-3b2c67aff067: Provides them with a balance in their lives
options.751aa7f0-e016-4ce4-8674-659620d806c3: Should consider sports as a mandatory subject
options.6a3372b5-ce95-4e3c-a4a7-04c61718873e: Keep students focus on academic subjects

content.questionName: Lis 6h30 - Part 4 - Topic : sport competition in school.
content.listeningScript:
Many people question whether sports are beneficial or harmful to children’s development. This is not an easy question to answer. Sports are often understood as inherently competitive, which makes it debatable whether they are good or bad. However, when the competitive element is excluded, sports play a crucial role in children’s development. They provide opportunities for socializing and learning essential life skills that are not typically taught in the classroom, such as teamwork, communication, and resilience. On the other hand, competitive sports can have negative effects. By this, I mean that constantly comparing one child to another to determine who is better or worse can be harmful. Many students thrive in neutral, active environments where cooperation is encouraged, rather than in competitive settings.

It is extremely important to recognize that sports are essential for children’s development, serving as a counterbalance to the academic focus of classrooms. Schools should view sports not as a means of fostering competition, but as a way to promote cooperation, physical wellness, and holistic growth.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing the Internet. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: There is too much information on the Internet
Finding information on the Internet requires skills
The use of internet affects the way we think
The internet makes young people less patient

content.questionName: Lis - Part 2 - Topic : internet - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hi, Emma. You know, I’ve been thinking a lot about how much the internet has improved lately. It’s really starting to shape the way our lives develop.

Woman: Really? In what way?

Man: Well, take a look at this article I found. It talks about how the internet influences everything—from how we learn to how we make decisions.

Woman: Ah, so you’re saying the internet gives us access to a lot of information? That's true in my opinion.

Man: Hmm… not exactly. Not exactly. I think the information is helpful, but you actually need strong searching skills to find what’s useful. And the problem is, too many people fall for fake news.

Woman: That’s a fair point. Just last week, I saw this post about a new product that promises fast weight loss. It had thousands of likes and comments, but when I looked into it, it turned out to be a complete scam.

Man: That’s a perfect example. I really believe there should be stricter control. Authorities need to take legal action and provide clearer guidelines. The internet has a huge impact on the way people think and behave.

Woman: I’m not sure I agree with that part. I think we just need to be more careful when using the internet. People should take responsibility to double-check things before buying or sharing. If we bring in too many laws, we might limit people’s freedom to express their opinions.

Man: I get your point, but still, we can’t ignore the damage some of this content causes. There’s so much being created every second—especially short-form content. It’s fast and addictive. And honestly, I think it’s making young people more impatient.

Woman: I completely agree. My younger cousin can’t even sit through a one-minute video without skipping ahead. It’s like no one wants to wait anymore.

Man: Exactly. That’s why I think some sort of regulation is necessary—not to control people’s voices, but to help improve the quality of what we see online.

Woman: That might help, as long as we don’t go too far with restrictions.

Professor: Good morning, Alex. I've just finished reading your thesis, and I must say, it's very well done. You've put a lot of effort into it.

Student: Thank you, Professor! I'm glad you liked it. I worked hard on it.

Professor: It shows. Your research is thorough, and your arguments are clear. I actually think you should consider presenting it at the upcoming student conference.

Student: Wow, really? That sounds exciting! But I'm not sure how that works. Could you tell me more about it?

Professor: Of course. The conference is a great opportunity to share your findings with a wider audience. You would prepare a short presentation, around 10–15 minutes, and then answer some questions from the audience. It's a good way to get feedback and gain experience speaking publicly.

content.questionName: Lis Sick - Part 4 - Topic : professionalism at work
content.listeningScript:
Good morning, everyone! Today, I want to talk about professionalism and how it has changed over the years. To be seen as a professional, it’s essential to be friendly, open-minded, and willing to help others. An optimistic attitude not only makes a good impression but also creates a better work environment.

Additionally, with the rapid changes in technology and globalization, our definition of professionalism is no longer the same as it was 40 years ago. In the past, being professional often meant simply dressing well and following strict rules. Now, it includes being adaptable, understanding different cultures, and using technology effectively.

As we continue to evolve in our careers, we must embrace these changes and redefine what it means to be a professional. By doing so, we can better meet the needs of our diverse workplaces and succeed in today’s fast-paced world. Thank you!

content.questionName: Lis Sick - Part 3 - Topic : changes in the work place - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hey Mike, why are you packing your things?

Woman: Oh, I just submitted my resignation today.

Man: You did? Why’s that?

Woman: I feel like I need a change of environment. I’ve been working here for the past five years, and I think it’s time to try something new and more challenging.

Man: But wouldn’t it be safer to stick with what you’re doing? In this volatile job market, who knows what could happen?

Woman: That’s exactly why I’m leaving. In such a fast-paced world, nothing is guaranteed or stable. Sure, some people succeed here, but some businesses will inevitably fail. The key is to adapt and grow with the changes.

Man: So you don’t think a secure promotion can give you satisfaction? That’s surprising. For me, climbing the career ladder, getting promoted, and being recognized is a big motivator. You can’t expect that if you keep switching jobs.

Woman: True, but motivation and satisfaction don’t always come from staying in one place or gaining recognition. For me, it comes from continuous learning and exploring new fields. Becoming a lifelong learner naturally leads to expertise in your area, so in the long run, you still reach your goals.

Man: That’s a fair point. But don’t you think taking on a new role is risky? Many jobs are being replaced by machines, and technology keeps improving. If you don’t quickly build your reputation, it could put you out of work. Not that I think technology is bad for the economy—it will certainly create new opportunities and advancement—but it’s still a concern.

Woman: That’s a valid argument I’m still considering. From a broader perspective, rising unemployment could have serious consequences for society as a whole.

content.questionName: Lis Sick - Part 2 - Topic : Running
content.listeningScript:
F: Obviously, running in the park or forest is ideal, but I live in the city center, which means access to such places is very limited. Running on the street is an option for many people; however, I find it quite dangerous because of the heavy traffic. Fortunately, there’s a local gym near my home that I visit regularly to stay fit. I also enjoy exercising with my friends there, which really helps keep me motivated.


M: I’m not a keen person myself, but I try to do some light activities to stay energetic throughout the day. There’s a fitness center right across the street from where I live, but it’s usually crowded. I used to go jogging in the park, but since moving to a coastal city, I prefer running on the sand in the late afternoon. I don’t really see it as a workout — more as a way to unwind and release stress after work.


F: My husband and I usually go for walks in the forest when we have time, and I must admit it’s quite a relaxing experience. However, when it comes to running, I wouldn’t recommend it because there are too many branches and uneven paths that could be dangerous for runners. Instead, I jog early in the morning around my neighborhood, where there’s little traffic. It’s safe, peaceful, and completely free.


M: I live by the seaside, which for many people sounds like the perfect place to exercise. Unfortunately, the beach gets too crowded with tourists during peak seasons. That’s why most locals prefer to walk or jog at fitness centers. As for me, I’m lucky to have access to a local stadium that once hosted a national athletic event. It’s now open to the public, and I can run properly on the track in a professional setting.

content.questionName: Lis Room 301 - Part 4 - Topic: research into happiness
content.listeningScript:
Radio MC: Good morning, listeners! Today, we’re diving into a recent research study on happiness that has sparked quite a bit of discussion. Unfortunately, it seems that the media has focused more on sensational headlines rather than accurately reporting the core findings of the research. As a result, many people are left with a distorted understanding of what truly contributes to happiness.

While numerous studies have attempted to uncover the secrets to a happy life, it’s important to recognize that there may never be a conclusive answer. Happiness is a complex and personal experience, influenced by a variety of factors unique to each individual.

Instead of seeking a one-size-fits-all solution, we should focus on understanding our own needs and values. Remember, happiness is not a destination but a journey, and it’s crucial to approach it with an open mind. Stay tuned for more insights and discussions on this fascinating topic!

content.questionName: Lis Room 301 - Part 2 - Topic : shopping online
content.listeningScript:
Speaker A:

I’ve always been a bit short on time, especially with my busy work schedule. That’s why I prefer shopping online—it really helps me save so much time. Instead of spending hours in stores, I can quickly browse through different websites, compare prices, and make my purchase in just a few clicks. It’s so convenient, especially when I need something urgently. I can even shop during my lunch break or late at night. It fits perfectly with my lifestyle, and I don’t have to worry about rushing to a store before it closes.


Speaker B:

For me, one of the main reasons I shop online is because it’s usually more affordable. I’ve noticed that many online stores offer discounts, and I can often find cheaper prices than I would in physical shops. Plus, I can compare products easily, making sure I’m getting the best deal. I also don’t have to spend money on transportation or parking, which adds up in the long run. It’s a great way to stick to my budget while still getting everything I need.


Speaker C:

The biggest advantage of shopping online for me is the fact that I don’t have to leave my house. I love how products get delivered straight to my doorstep, especially when I order something heavy or large. It saves me the hassle of carrying things back from the store. I also like how fast the delivery can be, sometimes arriving the very next day. It makes life so much easier, especially when I have a busy week and can’t make it to the shops.


Speaker D:

What I love about shopping online is the incredible variety of products available. When I go to a store, I’m limited to what’s in stock, but online, there’s so much more choice. I can find different brands, styles, and even products that aren’t available locally. It’s great for finding unique items or hard-to-find sizes. I can spend time browsing until I find exactly what I’m looking for without feeling rushed. It gives me the freedom to explore all my options.

content.title: A critic is giving opinions about a restaurant

subQuestions.title: What are the critic’s opinions about the restaurant?
What can compete with online food delivery?

content.questionName: Lis The college - Part 4 - Topic : restaurant
content.listeningScript:
As someone who’s reviewed dining experiences for years, I was looking forward to my visit to La Bella Bistro. The location and ambiance are certainly inviting; however, my overall experience left much to be desired. While the food itself was decent, the real issue lies with the service. From the moment I arrived, it was clear that the staff were either overwhelmed or under-trained. I had to wait far too long for basic requests, and when I did finally receive attention, it was rushed and impersonal. This level of service really detracts from what should be a pleasant evening.


Now, in an age where online food delivery has become so convenient, restaurants need to focus on what sets them apart. What can compete with the ease of ordering from home is the feeling of being truly valued and welcomed. Diners aren’t just looking for good food; they want an experience. A warm greeting, attentive service, and the sense that their presence matters—these are the things that make customers want to return. Unfortunately, at La Bella Bistro, that element was noticeably lacking, and it’s something they need to address if they hope to stand out in today’s competitive market.

content.title: Listen to two people discuss urban farming. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Living space is more important than farming space
Urban farming is appealing
Urban farming will benefit the local economy
Rural farming is needed for more food

content.questionName: Lis The college - Part - Topic : urban farming - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hey, Car, have you read the article about urban farming?

Woman: Urban farming? What exactly is it?

Man: Well, it’s about growing food in urban areas, like on rooftops or unused spaces, to help address food supply issues in cities.

Woman: You mean farming in cities? How could that even work? Cities are already overcrowded. There isn’t enough space for housing, let alone farming. Urban farming will take up land that could be used for accommodation.

Man: I think it makes sense. More people from rural areas are moving to cities, and food has become a critical issue. It’s vital that we adapt over time.

Woman: That’s exactly my point. Where are all these people supposed to live?

Man: You don’t have to take "urban farming" literally. It’s not about large-scale farming right away. Small changes are necessary. Over time, we need to find ways to balance ecological and economic needs.

Woman: Sure, I support green initiatives, but they need to be practical. How can this approach actually work?

Man: Unused spaces that are too small for housing can be converted into farming areas. If done right, this could be both beneficial and visually attractive, like turning them into green spaces or local parks.

Woman: I still think this could have negative effects, especially on rural areas where traditional farmers might lose their jobs if urban farming takes over.

Man: You should think of it as a supplement, not a replacement. For rural areas, producing vegetables closer to where they’re consumed can actually be beneficial. It saves on transportation costs and uses resources more efficiently.

Woman: But this is mostly about food, right? I don’t think urban farming can solve the problem of scarcity. Cities just can’t realistically support large-scale farming. Rural farming is still a more practical option.

Man: That’s true, and I agree. But changes need to happen. Sooner or later, urban farming will become a key trend for the future.

Reviewer: Today, I want to share my thoughts on a fascinating book about the life of renowned scientist Dr. Emily Carter. One of the standout features of this book is that the way of writing is exciting for readers. The author has a talent for bringing complex scientific concepts to life, making it an engaging experience.

While some may expect a heavy focus on technical details, this book skillfully balances science with storytelling, ensuring that it remains accessible. It’s definitely not more of a textbook than a biography; instead, it invites readers into the scientist’s world in a relatable way.

Overall, I’d say it has been written for a general audience. content.title: Listen to two people discus Politics. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Young people are now more into politics
Social media changed politics
People are now better informed on politics
More women pursuit politics

content.questionName: Lis suggest to drink 9Am Sunday - Part 3 - Topic : politics - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hi Sam, what are you reading? You look really focused.

Woman: Take a look at this article — it says the number of young people voting in state-level elections has been gradually increasing over the years.

Man: I’m not surprised at all. Young people today are much better informed than we were back then. They have constant access to news online and a clearer understanding of what’s happening around the world. It’s only natural that they want leaders with integrity to represent them.

Woman: Yeah, true. I remember when we were their age, all we cared about was finding decent jobs and making a living.

Man: That’s largely thanks to online forums and social media platforms, which spread information so quickly. Young people have a real advantage when it comes to technology. There’s no doubt that reaching them through these channels is becoming the new trend.

Woman: You might be partly right. But I don’t think technology alone can transform politics. Traditional media is still the main and most trusted source of political information.

Man: If that’s the case, then why are young people the ones showing more interest in politics?

Woman: Actually, it’s not just the young. This report here says that political awareness among the general population has increased over time — and I completely agree with that.

Man: Well, that’s not really my area of expertise. But I have noticed that more women are getting involved in politics — a field that used to be dominated by men.

Woman: Yes, absolutely. In today’s global context, gender equality is a major concern, and I believe we’ll see more female politicians in the future.

content.questionName: Lis suggest to drink 9Am Sunday - Part 2 - Topic : The use of the internet
content.listeningScript:
Woman A: I used to go on the Internet to play games, especially when I was in high school. Back then, I would spend hours competing with strangers online, which was fun but also a bit of a waste of time. As I got older, my interests changed. Nowadays, whenever I have some free time, I mostly use the Internet to stream movies and TV shows. It’s so convenient because I don’t need to wait for downloads, and the selection is much bigger than in any local shop. Sometimes I even watch documentaries to learn something new. I still play games occasionally, but watching films is definitely the main reason I go online now.”


Man B: At our college, we had to study educational software programs and use online databases to complete our coursework. I remember how difficult it was at first, since I wasn’t very good with technology. Over time, though, I realized that without the Internet I wouldn’t have been able to gather enough information for essays or prepare properly for exams. I often had to download journal articles, check references, and sometimes even join online discussion forums to ask questions. Of course, I also use the Internet for entertainment, like everyone else, but most of my time online is spent working on assignments. It has become an essential tool for my studies.”


Woman C: Quite a few of my friends have moved away to study or work in other cities, so it’s not easy for us to meet in person anymore. Thanks to social media and messaging apps, though, we manage to stay in touch almost every day. I can send them photos or short videos, and they can do the same, which makes me feel as if we’re still close. Sometimes we even organize online group calls just to catch up, which is really fun. Of course, I occasionally use the Internet for music or shopping, but my main reason for logging in is to talk with my friends. Without that, I think I would feel quite lonely.”


Man D: I’m not a fan of studying online, and I don’t usually spend much time watching films or chatting with people on the Internet. What I actually find most useful is being able to check travel details. Since I often need to move around the city, I rely on websites and apps to look up bus routes, train connections, and even bicycle rental services. This saves me a lot of time compared to asking around or waiting at the station. Occasionally, I also read the news or check the weather, but the main reason I connect to the Internet is to plan my journeys. It makes travelling much easier and less stressful.”

content.title: Listen to two people discuss the arts. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Art is only suitable for the privileged few
The government should invest more in arts
Children should be exposed to art early
In the future, art will become more accessible

content.questionName: Lis Suggest To drink 3250 - Part 3 - Topic: Arts - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hey, are you going to the art exhibition this weekend?

Woman: Probably not. Honestly, I feel like art is only really suitable for the privileged few. Tickets can be expensive, and a lot of galleries feel intimidating.

Man: I get what you mean, but I think that’s exactly why the government should invest more in the arts. If there were more funding, museums and events could be cheaper and more open to everyone.

Woman: Maybe, but even when it’s free, some people still feel like they don’t belong. Art spaces often seem designed for people with money or a certain background.

Man: That’s why it should start early. I think children should be exposed to art as soon as possible—through school trips, art classes, and simple creative activities.

Woman: Yes, I agree with that. If kids grow up visiting museums and trying different forms of art, they won’t feel scared of it later.

Man: Exactly. And I actually believe in the future, art will become more accessible. With online exhibitions, virtual tours, and social media, people can enjoy art without having to travel or pay high prices.

Woman: That’s true. Technology can help, but I still worry that high-level art education and expensive performances will stay exclusive.

Man: Maybe some parts will, but overall I think access will improve—especially if governments and schools support it more.

Woman: I hope so. At least we both agree that children should get the chance to experience art early.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing auditions. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statement:, the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Auditions are most important
Actors respond best to strong scripts
Theater acting and screen acting are different
Actors should be praised as much as possible

content.questionName: Lis 250 Pounds - Part 3 - Topic: Audition - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: You have directed some of the most successful films. What do you think are the key elements that make a movie stand out?

Woman: Well, nowadays, special effects and technology reduce the amount of work and time needed during the movie making process, which also enhances the quality of the movie. However, choosing the right person for the role is what's really important. The right actor can deliver the story well and communicate messages.

Man: You mean Casting? That is absolutely true. Many famous actors and actresses refuse to audition. They believe that their expertise and previous work speak for themselves. For me, this is rather a false claim.

Woman: Yes, this can be true for small roles. However, if you've already got a person in mind for the important ones, trying out a few lines for 15 minutes would not likely to change what you think.

Man: How about improvisation? For experienced actors, usually I have a scene and guide them on how I want it to be done and they can improvise. This gives them greater control of their performance.

Woman: Yeah, that's true. However actors and actresses prefer something based on. A strong script can always come in handy, as it provides insightful guidelines on what and how things should be carried out precisely.

Man: Hmmm, I can see that. How about actors with a theater background? Are the requirements for them different from those initially professionally trained in the field?

Woman: I think film acting and theater acting are quite two different concepts. Some of these actors fail to realize that sometimes less is more.

Man: Exaggerating feelings and noticeable escalation of emotions are to avoid if ones wants to be a film actor. Many actors and actresses often doubt themselves on whether they have expressed character's emotions appropriately.

Woman: It's true. Therefore it is crucial that we, as directors, it is our job to give them encouragement. Showing approval to their work is one way to nurture talents in the industry, especially for young talents.

Woman: Yes. And also, directors should provide actors and actresses with solid comments on what areas should be improved. Our feedback is vital for the success of bringing fictional characters to live.

content.questionName: Lis 10h15 - Part 4 - Topic : the advertising industry
content.listeningScript:
Advertising in sports has become a double-edged sword. Many fans grow tired of seeing the same commercials repeatedly during games and events. This constant bombardment can lead to frustration, causing viewers to feel disconnected from the sport they love. When ads overshadow the actual games, it detracts from the excitement and intensity that fans crave, making them less enthusiastic about tuning in. Therefore, many TV series and sports events have been damaged by overexposure.

In terms of sports, overexposure can generate negative publicity for the sport itself. Fans may start to associate their favorite teams and players with annoying advertisements rather than the thrilling action on the field. This shift in perception can reduce attendance at games and viewership on TV, as people become disillusioned with the sport’s focus on commercial interests.

In the end, while advertising can bring in revenue and promote the sport, it’s crucial to find a balance. Too much exposure can lead to viewer fatigue and diminish the overall appeal of the series or sport. By prioritizing the game itself and minimizing intrusive ads, sports organizations can maintain fan engagement and protect their brand image.

content.questionName: Lis 10h15 - Part 4 - Topic : television series

A famous TV series called Mystery City was recently broadcast, and it caught the audience’s attention from the start. The first episode was filled with suspense and surprising twists that left viewers eager for more. The engaging storyline and strong characters made it easy for people to connect with the show, which quickly became a topic of conversation. Social media buzzed with reactions and theories, making it a true phenomenon.

Beyond just entertaining, Mystery City has also helped its network reach new customers. The show attracted a diverse audience, including younger viewers who might not have watched traditional TV before. This is important for marketing because it shows how a single series can expand a network’s reach and boost subscriptions. With clever promotions and partnerships, the series brought in new fans who may now explore other shows on the platform.

Overall, Mystery City is not just a popular series; it’s a powerful tool for building a community around a brand. The combination of captivating storytelling and strategic marketing has made it a success that other networks will likely try to replicate. As the series continues, it will be interesting to see how it evolves and what new customers it brings in.

Topic : television series

- It has the consistent quality throughout

- Viewer habits influence the way that series are made

content.title: Listen to two people discuss beauty. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: People share similar ideas about beauty
Ideas about beauty change over time
Beauty can be found in unlikely places
Traditional ideas about beauty are going to change

content.questionName: Lis 10h15 - Part 3 - Topic : the subject of beauty - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Today, we are diving into the concept of beauty. The word "beauty" itself may seem simple, but as we look deeper and consider different aspects, it is actually more complex than we think. Do you agree, Mark?

Woman: Absolutely, Tina. Beauty is not just what we can see or observe, and it's fascinating to see how people interpret it. One concept I like to share is that beauty is a universal constant. Of course, different cultures and nations have different understandings and standards of beauty. However, it all comes down to harmony and symmetry. I have no argument with this view.

Man: Well, my research suggests something different. Beauty has no objective meaning, which means it’s all based on personal perspective. Just like music or films, there is no universal standard. Moreover, throughout history, standards of beauty that were accepted by one generation may be rejected by the next. As time goes by, the concept of beauty evolves.

Woman: Sure, that’s true. However, people still appreciate what was considered beautiful by earlier generations. So beauty is, in a way, passed on.

Man: Of course, physical appearances can be passed on, but beauty is not just limited to physical things. It also appears in nature.

Woman: I agree. It's fascinating to see beauty in ordinary things. Nature, on the other hand, has long been an inspiration for beauty. You can see that in many works of art.

Man: But with technology, everyone can become an artist, so there’s no doubt that the traditional concepts once considered beautiful might not hold true for future generations.

Woman: I’m unable to predict that. Still, one thing we can all agree on is that beauty is a complicated concept with layers of meaning that are not always easy to understand.

content.questionName: Lis 10h15 - Part 2 - Topic : studying habits
content.listeningScript:
Woman A: I don’t usually revise anything after school. During lectures, if I have any questions, I ask the lecturer straight away so I won’t have to worry about them later. I used to go to the library to finish my work, but now I prefer staying at home. I like studying in different spots — sometimes on the sofa, sometimes at the kitchen counter, or even on the floor. Changing my study location keeps things interesting and makes learning more comfortable.


Man B: I start doing my homework right away as soon as I receive it. I feel stressed if I leave tasks unfinished, so I like completing them immediately. To focus properly, I need a completely quiet space with no distractions. That’s why I usually choose to study early in the morning when everyone else is asleep. The calm atmosphere at that time helps me concentrate and finish my work efficiently.


Woman C: I know many people lose concentration even with the slightest background noise, but music helps me focus. I often play soft tunes while studying because it keeps me alert and motivated. Sometimes I study with a friend at a library or café, which is fun, but I prefer studying one-on-one rather than in a big group because larger gatherings can be distracting. A relaxed session with music and a friend works best for me.


Man D: I study late in the evening when everyone is sleeping. It’s not that I focus better at night, but there are no other distractions. I put on my headphones and start working, and often I get a lot done before morning. The quiet nighttime environment helps me concentrate and stay productive. Even though it isn’t my ideal time, this routine has become surprisingly effective.

content.questionName: Lis 10h15 - He has to drive to work - anh ấy học lái xe để làm gì?
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hey, Sarah. I’ve got some news—I’m moving to a new place.

Woman: Oh really? That sounds exciting! Where’s your new place?

Man: It’s actually pretty far from my workplace, and the public transport there isn’t great. So, I’ve been thinking, I need to learn how to drive.

Woman: Yeah, that makes sense. It’s hard to rely on public transport if it’s not reliable. Have you ever driven before?

Man: Not really. I’ve always used buses and trains, but now it looks like I don’t have a choice. I need to get a license.

Woman: You’ll get the hang of it. Driving will definitely make your commute easier. Are you planning to take lessons soon?

Man: Yeah, I’m going to sign up for a driving school next week. Hopefully, I can get it done quickly.

content.title: Listen to a woman explaining her morning routine to her friend. Why do women get up early?

content.listeningScript: I usually wake up early each day before anyone else. Some people get up early to get to work on time or to take care of their kids, but for me, it’s all about enjoying that calm before the busyness begins. I enjoy this quiet time because it helps me start my day peacefully. It’s nice to have a few moments to myself, sipping coffee and planning my day ahead.

content.title: Listen to a nutrition expert. What time is the best for children to eat fruit?

content.listeningScript: Hello, everyone! I’m here to talk about nutrition and how important it is for our health. Eating fruits is very beneficial, especially for children. Fruits have vitamins and minerals that help kids grow strong and stay healthy. The best time for children to eat fruit is in the mornings. This gives them energy for the day ahead. You can add fruit to breakfast, like in a smoothie or with yogurt. It’s a delicious and healthy way to start the day! So, let’s encourage our kids to eat more fruit in the morning! Thank you!

I like to wear smart clothes because I work in an office. I go by bus every day, which takes about 30 minutes. I enjoy looking out the window and listening to music on my way. When I arrive at the office, I start my day by checking emails and planning my tasks. I have meetings with my team, and we work together on projects.

content.audioUrl: F - a plan for the city-171125172926.mp3

subQuestions.title: What is one of the main criticisms of the plan for the city?

options.26d03d5e-5d7a-4250-8260-043b4350c36f: It places too much emphasis on public transportation.
options.a1d3ee54-2733-4b0c-ade9-8a6ae2afa1cd: It is too expensive to implement the plan.
options.17d1d5c8-80ab-4ef7-94f6-64a61977405f: It does not provide enough alternatives to driving.

subQuestions.title: What challenge is the plan for the city likely to face?

options.bf30d54e-5516-46f2-9d77-1963cfa939a5: It could face difficulties in gaining government approval.
options.0227c36d-b2e9-4443-a52e-f28afd96eac9: It may be delayed due to funding issues.
options.25ae48c4-6f53-4239-a6b5-3cb23888d4fc: It is likely to meet resistance from local communities.

content.questionName: 1.5 Pound - Part 4 - Topic : Regional Development Planning
content.listeningScript:
Ladies and gentlemen of the press, thank you for joining us today to discuss our Regional Development Plan. As we move forward with this ambitious project, I’d like to address some of the concerns that have been raised.

Now, I’ve heard whispers about our plan being too expensive or placing excessive emphasis on public transportation. Let me assure you, these are not accurate representations of our vision. Our budget has been carefully calculated, and we believe it strikes the right balance between fiscal responsibility and necessary improvements.

However, I will acknowledge that one of the main criticisms we’ve received is that our plan doesn’t provide enough alternatives to driving. This is a valid concern, and I want to assure you that we’re taking it seriously. We’re actively exploring additional options to diversify our transportation network and reduce reliance on personal vehicles.

Some have suggested that we might face delays due to funding issues or difficulties in gaining government approval. While we always prepare for potential hurdles, I’m confident that our thorough planning and strong relationships with various government bodies will help us navigate any bureaucratic challenges smoothly.

The real challenge we’re anticipating, and the one we’re preparing for most diligently, is the likelihood of resistance from local communities. Change can be difficult, and we understand that. That’s why we’re emphasizing better communication and transparency with our stakeholders and working closely with neighborhood representatives to address concerns and incorporate local feedback.

We believe this Regional Development Plan is crucial for our area’s future, and we’re dedicated to making it a reality. Thank you for your attention, and I’ll now take your questions.

content.title: An expert is giving comments on a newly released series.

subQuestions.title: What part of the movie is disappointing?
What is the expert comment on the movie industry?

options.0c6e465c-f940-4fb7-ba87-68e3322fbac8: Technology will soon replace human actors.
options.f72b282a-fa4d-4be7-962e-336884ded0f3: The new industry demands are negatively influencing script production.
options.9956f95a-34ce-403f-b591-73aa04a6fc02: New story plots should be invented to capture the audience’s interest.

content.questionName: 1.5 Pound - Part 4 - Topic : a newly released series.
content.listeningScript:
As a long-time observer of the film industry, I couldn’t help but notice that The Silver Horizon, while visually stunning, suffers in certain key areas. The first half of the film, in particular, feels disconnected in terms of character development. Now, while I understand the need for certain creative liberties, I found the dialogue to be rather unrealistic. It’s almost as if the characters are speaking lines that were meant for a different era or context altogether, and it really pulls the viewer out of the experience. The conversation between the protagonist and his mentor, for example, is meant to be emotionally charged, yet the words used were so stiff that it felt forced, almost like a stage play instead of natural human interaction.

Moving on, I think this issue ties into a broader problem in today’s filmmaking landscape. We’re seeing more and more that the demands of the modern industry are negatively influencing the way scripts are produced. It seems studios are prioritizing fast turnaround times and market trends over well-thought-out storytelling. As a result, many films, like this one, end up feeling rushed and lacking in substance. The pressure to churn out content quickly has, in my opinion, led to a decline in the quality of scripts we’re seeing on the big screen. Writers aren’t given enough time to craft genuine, layered stories, and it shows in films like The Silver Horizon.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing university. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Technology helps make education more accessible
Social interaction is important
The diverse curriculum is not an advantage
University eompetition should be encouraged

content.questionName: 1.5 Pound - Part 3 - Topic : University - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hi Joseph! I heard you’ve enrolled in an online course about technology. How’s it going so far?

Woman: Oh, hi Emily. I have to say, it’s really lived up to my expectations. I never imagined online learning could be so easy and engaging. We complete all the tasks and group projects just like we used to at university. I think it’s a great way for working people like me to continue studying.

Man: That’s wonderful. I truly believe this is thanks to the advancement of the internet, which allows people to connect and gain knowledge more efficiently. I’m sure distance learning will soon become an essential part of university education.

Woman: I agree, but I think it will serve more as a supplementary model rather than replacing traditional on-campus learning.

Man: What makes you say that?

Woman: Well, gaining knowledge is only one part of a student’s development. We can’t overlook the social aspect. Interacting with classmates helps students understand complex social relationships, develop transferable skills, and build the social competence needed to navigate real-life situations.

Man: I understand your point, but the primary goal of education—especially higher education—is still about gaining knowledge. As long as students can learn effectively, whether online or offline shouldn’t matter.

Woman: True, but attending only in-person courses can be quite challenging, especially when students have multiple subjects to manage. Online learning definitely helps them improve their knowledge and skills, though time management can be a real issue.

Man: I suppose having too many course options might also lead to scattered learning. Students end up knowing a bit of everything but not specializing in anything. These days, universities often open more programs mainly for profit. Fierce competition could really harm the true purpose of education.

Woman: That’s certainly true in some cases. But the reality is, education has become a business. To attract more students and generate income, institutions have no choice but to compete with one another, which in my opinion, actually facilitates advancement.

These things can make the air dirty, but in the countryside, there’s a bigger issue. Farmers often start fires to clean their fields. They burn old plants and grass. These fires make a lot of smoke that rises into the air. This is bad because the smoke can hurt animals and make people sick. We need to find better ways to clean fields without using fire.

content.title: Listen to a man discussing goal setting. Choose the correct answers.

subQuestions.title: What does the speaker say about short-term goals?

options.25950cee-3e0d-47e7-929a-194a68c0cb6e: It allows you to be more flexible
options.ca05ef66-4e19-4c08-9517-0f594dcbdf5c: It only apply to specific situations or certain types of people
options.52b1b842-a7ed-4b28-88cc-6877ab44c494: It creates pressure and limits creativity

subQuestions.title: What is the speaker's opinion about goal setting?

options.b2388fc8-d51f-4e6b-b4dc-d0fa2a85817f: It can bring about opportunities for individuals
options.985374f4-3fe8-4336-8758-7dbf9284744c: It can prevent you from making mistakes
options.61a02b8b-c7f7-473e-a9bb-acb14d771ed4: It can lead to confusion and distraction

content.questionName: Topic : Goal setting
content.listeningScript:
Man: When discussing short-term goals, many people mistakenly think they only apply to specific situations or certain types of people. Some believe these goals create pressure and limit creativity, making it seem like they’re not worth the effort. However, this view is quite misleading. In reality, short-term goals can actually be very flexible. They allow you to adjust your plans as life changes. For example, if you set a goal to read a few chapters of a book in a week, that’s not rigid, but you can easily change that goal if unexpected things come up, like work commitments or social events.

Now, when we consider setting goals overall, there’s a common belief that having too many goals leads to confusion and distraction. Some argue that this approach complicates things and makes it difficult to focus on what really matters. However, this perspective fails to recognize that clear goals actually help prevent mistakes. They provide a sense of direction, guiding our choices. But if they lack structure or flexibility, we might miss opportunities for creativity. So, while both short-term and long-term goals can be useful, it’s important to strike a balance to avoid feeling overwhelmed.

content.title: Listen to two people discuss the local center. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Exhibitions should be different
The traditions are losing significance
The local festival will disappear soon
Schools are important

content.questionName: Lis - Part 3 - Topic : the local center - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Have you heard about the new local center opening next week? I think it will be a great place for exhibitions. But you know, I believe exhibitions should be different. They need to show new ideas, not just the same old things.

Woman: I agree that exhibitions should be interesting, but I’m not sure they need to be completely different. Sometimes, it’s nice to celebrate our traditions, even if they are losing significance.

Man: Yes, that’s true. But if we keep doing the same things, we might forget why those traditions are important. The more we change things, the more people will remember them!

Woman: I see your point. However, I worry that the local festivals will disappear soon. If people don’t care about them, they might stop celebrating altogether.

Man: That’s a good point, but I think we can make the festivals more exciting to attract people. We should include activities that everyone can enjoy, not just the same old customs.

Woman: I understand that. But let’s not forget how important schools are in keeping our traditions alive. They teach children about our culture and values. If schools don’t focus on traditions, who will?

Man: That’s true! Schools play a big role. But maybe parents should be the ones in charge of this. Keeping traditions is everyone's responsibility, not just schools or the education system.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing Community design. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Community design influences people’s behavior
Sense of community takes time
Work community and social community are the same
Technology improves the way community is formed

content.questionName: Lis Room 301 - Part 3 - Topic : Community - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hey, have you noticed how much effort cities are putting into improving neighborhood layouts these days?

Woman: You mean things like parks, shared courtyards, bike lanes? Yeah, I’ve seen that. I suppose it does make people interact more.

Man: Exactly. It’s fascinating how the way a space is designed can actually change how people relate to each other. When a place feels open and welcoming, people naturally feel more inclined to talk, connect, even help one another.

Woman: I never used to think much about it, but after I moved last year, I noticed how different things felt. The new place has a community garden, and I ended up chatting with neighbors I might never have met otherwise.

Man: That’s what I mean! I'm really hopeful that more cities will keep this trend going.

Woman: Yeah, I’m all for it. Still, I think there's more to forming bonds than just the environment. Even in the most community-friendly setting, you can’t expect people to feel a strong sense of connection right away.

Man: That’s fair. Though I believe that it happens more quickly than we think. When someone joins a new team or starts volunteering, they often start to feel like part of the group sooner than expected. You know, like a "natural process".

Woman: Maybe in some cases. But in my experience, when you move to a new town or start over in a completely different setting, it takes a while before you really feel integrated. It’s a gradual growth, not something that just clicks.

Man: Speaking of integration, I think community isn’t limited to a specific context. Whether it’s colleagues at work or friends outside, the essence is the same—feeling seen, supported, and involved, whichever the size or type of group doesn’t matter as much as the emotional connection people have within it

Woman: That’s an interesting point. I’m not so sure I’m the best person to judge that. I’ve mostly kept my work life and personal life pretty separate. Though these days, a lot of those connections don’t even happen face-to-face anymore.

Man: Totally. Online platforms are redefining what community means. I’ve seen people build strong support networks without ever meeting in person.

Woman: Same here. I joined a language exchange group online, and it's actually one of the most engaging communities I’ve been part of. Technology really has changed the game.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing changes in the workplace. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Continuity is important
Job security cant be guaranteed
Job satisfaction is important motivator
Technology is good for the economy

content.questionName: Lis Part 3 - Topic : changes in the work place - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hey Mike, why are you packing your things?

Woman: Oh, I just submitted my resignation today.

Man: You did? Why’s that?

Woman: I feel like I need a change of environment. I’ve been working here for the past five years, and I think it’s time to try something new and more challenging.

Man: But wouldn’t it be safer to stick with what you’re doing? In this volatile job market, who knows what could happen?

Woman: That’s exactly why I’m leaving. In such a fast-paced world, nothing is guaranteed or stable. Sure, some people succeed here, but some businesses will inevitably fail. The key is to adapt and grow with the changes.

Man: So you don’t think a secure promotion can give you satisfaction? That’s surprising. For me, climbing the career ladder, getting promoted, and being recognized is a big motivator. You can’t expect that if you keep switching jobs.

Woman: True, but motivation and satisfaction don’t always come from staying in one place or gaining recognition. For me, it comes from continuous learning and exploring new fields. Becoming a lifelong learner naturally leads to expertise in your area, so in the long run, you still reach your goals.

Man: That’s a fair point. But don’t you think taking on a new role is risky? Many jobs are being replaced by machines, and technology keeps improving. If you don’t quickly build your reputation, it could put you out of work. Not that I think technology is bad for the economy—it will certainly create new opportunities and advancement—but it’s still a concern.

Woman: That’s a valid argument I’m still considering. From a broader perspective, rising unemployment could have serious consequences for society as a whole.

Instead of simply listing famous landmarks, it encourages readers to step off the beaten path and discover hidden gems.
