Some might think it is a little bit difficult to navigate, but in reality, it makes each journey feel like an adventure, allowing travelers to create unforgettable memories and experiences that go beyond the typical sightseeing.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing Arts . Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Art is only suitable for the privileged few
The government should invest more in the arts
Children should be exposed to art early
In the future, art will become more accessible

content.questionName: Lis Part 3 - Topic : Arts - Nữ nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Woman: Have you heard about the recent public controversy over the government’s spending on arts and galleries?

Man: You mean the one that made the authorities announce they’ll issue an official statement this weekend?

Woman: Yeah, that’s the one — 1.6 million dollars. That’s a huge amount of money.

Man: I think that’s absolutely ridiculous. The money spent on the arts comes from our taxes, and there are far more urgent issues that need to be solved, like poverty, malnutrition, and unemployment. This money should be reallocated to deal with real-life problems that affect the economy.

Woman: That’s not a fair argument, don’t you think? I believe art is also a business sector that contributes to economic growth. Places with famous artistic reputations — like Hollywood, theatres, or opera houses — attract visitors and generate spending, even among ordinary people. Honestly, I think the investment should have been even higher.

Man: Maybe, but if that’s the case, why do popular art attractions only exist in big cities and in luxurious venues? Not everyone can afford such high prices for just a brief moment of entertainment or curiosity.

Woman: I think that all comes down to education. Students aren’t taught enough to appreciate not only the beauty but also the value behind each piece of art. These works are preserved and displayed not simply because they’re beautiful, but because they reflect the lifestyle, virtues, and beliefs we once held.

Man: I suppose you’re right. Even back in school, I never really understood why we had to analyze other people’s artwork. We mostly memorized interpretations written in textbooks just to pass exams, without ever taking time to observe the works carefully ourselves.

Woman: Well, that will certainly change in the near future with technological advancements. Soon, everyone will be able to view, comment on, and appreciate art in their own unique way.

Man: I guess we’ll have to wait and see.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing singers and music. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements, the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Singers play a good role for young people
Taste in music is a highly personal thing
Music is a universal language
Music can manipulate people's feelings

content.questionName: Lis - Part 3 - Topic : music and singer - Nữ nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: Hi Michael, have you heard about the new awards for young artists?

Woman: Yeah, it’s a major event! It’s inspiring to see young artists motivating the next generation.

Man: What exactly do you mean by that?

Woman: Many singers participate in charity work and donate money, which encourages their fans to give back as well.

Man: True, but I feel they aren’t always doing it solely for the sake of helping others.

Woman: I don’t think that’s entirely fair. It seems like you might be overlooking their talent and contributions to society.

Man: Well, I just don’t like them. So what?

Woman: Don’t you think that’s a bit subjective? Different generations have different tastes. For instance, traditional music we enjoy isn’t appealing to everyone; some find it dull.

Man: Absolutely. Music preferences are definitely personal. But honestly, I feel many contemporary artists don’t measure up to those from the ’90s.

Woman: What do you mean by that?

Man: I think music, as a form of emotional expression, can connect people globally, regardless of their background.

Woman: Maybe, but I can’t fully agree. Perhaps it’s because I don’t have an artistic background like you. You went to art school, right?

Man: Yes, but formal training isn’t necessary to appreciate art. For example, films use music to influence the audience’s emotions.

Woman: True. Sometimes music can make us feel emotions we weren’t expecting. But in some movies, the music feels overdone, like the drums force the feeling too much.

Man: That usually comes down to poor execution. When done correctly, music should enhance the scene naturally without drawing attention to itself.

Woman: That’s a good point. Subtle music really can elevate the overall experience without overpowering the viewer.

content.title: Listen to two people discussing politics . Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements: the man, the woman, or both the man and the woman. You can listen to the discussion twice.

subQuestions.title: Young people are more into politics
Social media changes politics
People are now better informed on politics
More women pursue politics

content.questionName: Lis Part 2 - Topic : politics - Nữ nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Woman: Hi Sam, what are you reading? You look really focused.

Man: Take a look at this article — it says the number of young people voting in state-level elections has been gradually increasing over the years.

Woman: I’m not surprised at all. Young people today are much better informed than we were back then. They have constant access to news online and a clearer understanding of what’s happening around the world. It’s only natural that they want leaders with integrity to represent them.

Man: Yeah, true. I remember when we were their age, all we cared about was finding decent jobs and making a living.

Woman: That’s largely thanks to online forums and social media platforms, which spread information so quickly. Young people have a real advantage when it comes to technology. There’s no doubt that reaching them through these channels is becoming the new trend.

Man: You might be partly right. But I don’t think technology alone can transform politics. Traditional media is still the main and most trusted source of political information.

Woman: If that’s the case, then why are young people the ones showing more interest in politics?

Man: Actually, it’s not just the young. This report here says that political awareness among the general population has increased over time — and I completely agree with that.

Woman: Well, that’s not really my area of expertise. But I have noticed that more women are getting involved in politics — a field that used to be dominated by men.

Man: Yes, absolutely. In today’s global context, gender equality is a major concern, and I believe we’ll see more female politicians in the future.

content.title:
A man and a woman are talking about urban farming. Read the opinions below and decide whose opinion matches the statements:


15-020925131746.mp3

subQuestions.title: Living space is more important than farming space    tentisspace
Urban farming sites can be visually appealing    tentisspace
Urban farming can benefit local economics    tentisspace
Urban farming cannot meet food needs    tentisspace

content.questionName: Lis Part 3 - Topic : urban farming - Nam nói trước
content.listeningScript:
Man: I’ve been reading a report on urban farming and its potential impact on city life. It’s fascinating how cities are starting to embrace this concept to tackle issues like food security and environmental sustainability. It got me thinking about how this could reshape urban living.

Woman: I find the idea of urban farming intriguing too, but I believe living space is more important than farming space. People need proper homes to thrive.

Man: I understand that perspective, but I have to say, farming space in urban areas is really appealing. It brings a bit of nature into the city and can enhance the overall environment.

Woman: I agree with that. Urban farming does have a lot of visual and ecological benefits. However, we really need to focus on the fact that there’s a pressing need for more food in our cities. That should be a priority.

Man: That’s a valid point, but I think farming space will also benefit the urban economy. It creates jobs and stimulates local businesses, which is essential for growth.

Woman: I see where you’re coming from, but while boosting the economy is great, we can’t overlook the immediate need for more food. Urban farming can help, but it shouldn’t replace the need for larger-scale solutions to food shortages.

Man: I agree that food scarcity is a serious issue, but if we can implement urban farming effectively, it can definitely contribute to alleviating that problem while also strengthening the economy.
